properties.areaDesc: Sevier Smoky Mountains; Unicoi; Southeast Monroe; Cocke Smoky Mountains; Blount Smoky Mountains; Southeast Carter; Southeast Greene; Johnson
properties.headline: Wind Advisory issued November 1 at 10:45AM EDT expiring November 2 at 2:00AM EDT by NWS Morristown TN
properties.description:
A fast moving cold front will move across the area today
producing strong and gusty southwesterly winds. Southwest winds
will increase to 15 to 30 mph with gusts over 40 mph over the
higher elevations and adjacent foothills. The winds will subside
this evening into tonight.
* WINDS...South 15 to 30 mph with gusts over 40 mph.

* TIMING...Today and tonight.

* IMPACTS...Gusty winds will blow around unsecured objects. Tree
limbs could be blown down and a few power outages may result.
properties.instruction:
A Wind Advisory means that winds of 26 to 39 mph and/or gusts of
40 to 57 mph are expected or occurring. Winds this strong can
make driving difficult...especially for high profile vehicles.
Use extra caution.

* Special Marine Warning for...

20 NM...

Pensacola Bay Area including Santa Rosa Sound...
Perdido Bay Area...
Waters from Pensacola FL to Pascagoula MS from 20 to 60 NM...

* Until 1115 AM CDT.

* At 942 AM CDT, strong thunderstorms capable of producing
waterspouts were located along a line extending from Escambia Bay
Bridge to near Perdido Pass to 21 nm south of Gulf Shores Beach to
29 nm south of Farewell Buoy, moving northeast at 25 knots.

HAZARD...Waterspouts and wind gusts to 40 knots.

SOURCE...Radar.

IMPACT...Waterspouts can easily overturn boats and create locally
hazardous seas. Small craft could be damaged in briefly
higher winds and suddenly higher waves.

* Locations impacted include...
Arnica Bay, Lillian Bridge, Big Lagoon, Pensacola Beach, Pensacola
Pass, Fort Pickens, East Bay, Pensacola Bay Bridge, Garcon Point
Bridge and Perdido Pass.
properties.instruction:
Move to safe harbor immediately as gusty winds and high waves are
expected.

Thunderstorms can produce sudden waterspouts. Waterspouts can easily
overturn boats and create locally hazardous seas. Seek safe harbor
immediately.

properties.description:

* Special Marine Warning for...
Coastal waters from Okaloosa-Walton County Line to Pensacola FL out
20 NM...
Coastal waters from Pensacola FL to Pascagoula MS out 20 NM...
Waters from Okaloosa-Walton County Line to Pensacola FL from 20 to
60 NM...
Waters from Pensacola FL to Pascagoula MS from 20 to 60 NM...

* Until 1045 AM CDT.

* At 913 AM CDT, strong thunderstorms capable of producing
waterspouts and wind gusts to nearly 50 knots were located along a
line extending from 22 nm south of Farewell Buoy to 40 nm south of
Sand Island Lighthouse to 54 nm east of Pilottown, moving east at
45 knots.

HAZARD...Waterspouts and wind gusts to nearly 50 knots.

SOURCE...Radar.

IMPACT...Waterspouts can easily overturn boats and create locally
hazardous seas. Small craft could be damaged in briefly
higher winds and suddenly higher waves.

* Locations impacted include...
Oriskany Reef.
properties.instruction:
Move to safe harbor immediately as gusty winds and high waves are
expected.

Thunderstorms can produce sudden waterspouts. Waterspouts can easily
overturn boats and create locally hazardous seas. Seek safe harbor
immediately.

properties.headline: Special Weather Statement issued November 1 at 9:09AM CDT by NWS Birmingham AL
properties.description:
At 909 AM CDT, Doppler radar was tracking strong thunderstorms along
a line extending from near West Blocton to near Talladega National
Forest to near Paul M Grist State Park to Selma to near Dallas Lake.
Movement was southeast at 40 mph.

Winds in excess of 40 mph will be possible with these storms.

Locations impacted include...
Selma, Calera, Clanton, Montevallo, Valley Grande, Centreville,
Jemison, Fort Deposit, Mosses, Hayneville, Selmont-West Selmont,
Thorsby, West Blocton, Autaugaville, White Hall, Maplesville, Wilton,
Gordonville, Billingsley and Lowndesboro.
properties.instruction:
Torrential rainfall is also occurring with these storms, and may lead
to localized flooding. Do not drive your vehicle through flooded
roadways.

These storms may intensify, so be certain to monitor local radio
stations and available television stations for additional information
and possible warnings from the National Weather Service.

properties.headline: Special Marine Warning issued November 1 at 8:43AM CDT expiring November 1 at 10:15AM CDT by NWS New Orleans LA
properties.description:
The National Weather Service in New Orleans has issued a

* Special Marine Warning for...
Coastal Waters from Boothville LA to Southwest Pass of the
Mississippi River out 20 nm...
Coastal Waters from Stake Island LA to Southwest Pass of the
Mississippi River from 20 to 60 nm...
Coastal waters from Pascagoula Mississippi to Stake Island
Louisiana out 20 to 60 NM...
Coastal waters from Southwest Pass of the Mississippi River to Port
Fourchon Louisiana from 20 to 60 NM...

* Until 1015 AM CDT.

* At 840 AM CDT, severe thunderstorms capable of producing
waterspouts were located along a line extending from 31 nm east of
Pilottown to 46 nm south of Southwest Pass Of the Mississippi
River, moving east at 50 knots.

HAZARD...Waterspouts and wind gusts to 40 knots.

SOURCE...Radar.

IMPACT...Waterspouts can quickly form and capsize boats...damage
vessels and oil rigs...and create suddenly higher waves.
Make sure all on board are in a secure location and
wearing life jackets. Expect wind gusts in excess of 34
knots and suddenly higher waves. Boats could sustain
damage or capsize. Make sure all on board are wearing
life jackets. Return to safe harbor if possible.

* Severe thunderstorms will remain over mainly open waters.
properties.instruction:
Move to safe harbor immediately as gusty winds and high waves are
expected.

Thunderstorms can produce sudden waterspouts. Waterspouts can easily
overturn boats and create locally hazardous seas. Seek safe harbor
immediately.

properties.areaDesc: Baldwin Coastal; Santa Rosa Coastal; Escambia Coastal; Okaloosa Coastal
properties.headline: Rip Current Statement issued November 1 at 8:06AM CDT expiring November 2 at 11:00AM CDT by NWS Mobile AL
properties.description:
* WHERE...The Gulf beaches of Alabama and the western Florida
Panhandle.

* SURF HEIGHTS...Building to 5 to 8 feet.

* TIMING...Dangerous surf heights expected this morning through
this evening. A high risk of rip currents is in effect through
Friday morning.

* Impacts...Frequent life-threatening rip currents are expected.
The surf is dangerous for all levels of swimmers.
properties.instruction:
There is a high risk of rip currents. Rip currents are life-
threatening to anyone entering the surf. Swim near a lifeguard.
If caught in a rip current remain calm. Don't fight the current.
Swim in a direction following the shoreline. If unable to escape,
face the shore and call or wave for help. If tired, float or
tread water until out of the rip current.

A High Surf Advisory means that high surf will affect beaches in
the advisory area, producing localized beach erosion and
dangerous swimming conditions.

NWSheadline: HIGH SURF ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 1 AM CDT FRIDAY... ...HIGH RIP CURRENT RISK REMAINS IN EFFECT THROUGH FRIDAY MORNING

properties.senderName: NWS El Paso TX/Santa Teresa NM
properties.headline: Freeze Warning issued November 1 at 6:51AM MDT expiring November 1 at 10:00AM MDT by NWS El Paso TX/Santa Teresa NM
properties.description:
Temperatures are falling rapidly over the Gila Region as
extensive high clouds move out of the area. Freezing conditions
are still expected early this morning.
* TEMPERATURES AND TIMING...Temperatures will fall into the
upper 20s to lower 30s over the foothills of the Gila Region
by dawn Thursday morning.

* IMPACTS...Sensitive vegetation may be damaged or killed.
Temperatures may be dangerous for animals left outdoors.
properties.instruction:
A Freeze Warning means sub-freezing temperatures are imminent or

sensitive vegetation. Bring pets indoors.

properties.headline: Special Weather Statement issued November 1 at 7:19AM CDT by NWS Paducah KY
properties.description:
Strong north winds behind a cold front will continue through late
this morning. Peak wind gusts from 30 to 40 mph were observed in
southeast Missouri overnight. These gusty winds will overspread
southern Illinois and southwest Indiana this morning.

A few trees have been blown down in southeast Missouri due to the
combination of gusty winds and saturated soil. Similar impacts are
possible in southern Illinois and southwest Indiana.

Exercise caution if you are outdoors this morning. Watch for loose
debris on roadways.

properties.areaDesc: Mobile, AL
properties.headline: Flood Advisory issued November 1 at 7:13AM CDT expiring November 1 at 10:15AM CDT by NWS Mobile AL
properties.description:
The National Weather Service in Mobile has issued a

* Urban and Small Stream Flood Advisory for...
Central Mobile County in southwestern Alabama...

* Until 1015 AM CDT.

* At 712 AM CDT, Doppler radar indicated heavy rain due to
thunderstorms. This will cause urban and small stream flooding in
the advisory area. Up to one inch of rain has already fallen...
with another one to two inches being possible.

* Some locations that will experience flooding include...
Midtown Mobile, Downtown Mobile, Prichard, Tillmans Corner,
Saraland, Theodore, Chickasaw, Semmes, I65 And I165, I65 And AL
158, I10 And I65 and Mobile Regional Airport.
properties.instruction:
Excessive runoff from heavy rainfall will cause flooding of small
creeks and streams, urban areas, highways, streets and underpasses
as well as other drainage areas and low lying spots.

properties.areaDesc: Christian; Daviess; Henderson; Warrick; Vanderburgh; Lyon; Gibson; Hopkins; Posey; Webster; Caldwell; Trigg; Pike; White; Todd; McLean; Spencer; Union; Hardin; Crittenden; Muhlenberg; Gallatin
properties.headline: Flood Watch issued November 1 at 7:06AM CDT expiring November 1 at 1:00PM CDT by NWS Paducah KY
properties.description:
The Flood Watch continues for

* Portions of southeast Illinois, western Kentucky, and all of
southwest Indiana. In southern Illinois, the watch continues to
include Gallatin, Hardin, and White Counties. In western
Kentucky, Caldwell, Christian, Crittenden, Daviess, Henderson,
Hopkins, Lyon, McLean, Muhlenberg, Todd, Trigg, Union, and
Webster Counties remain in the watch.

* Until 1 PM CDT this afternoon

* Widespread heavy rain will taper off to light showers from
southwest to northeast later this morning. Storm total rainfall
in the watch area is forecast to range from 2 to 4 inches, with
isolated amounts to 5 inches in northwest Kentucky.

* Localized flooding of low lying and flood-prone areas is
likely, as well as urban street flooding. Flood Warnings are
already in effect for some areas. Falling leaves may also clog
drainage systems and impede the normal course of water runoff.
In addition, expect some river flooding later this week into
early next week.
properties.instruction:
A Flood Watch means there is a potential for flooding based on
current forecasts.

You should keep monitoring updated forecasts and be alert for
Flood Warnings. Be prepared to take action should flooding occur.

increase to 15 to 25 knots late today and tonight ahead of an
approaching cold front. Seas will build to 5 to 8 feet tonight.

30 knots with seas building to 7 to 10 feet. Winds Saturday will
shift to west northwest and diminish to 10 to 15 knots late. Seas
are forecast to subside below 6 feet Saturday evening.

* SEAS...7 to 10 feet.

and/or seas of 6 feet or greater are expected to produce
hazardous wave conditions to small craft. Inexperienced mariners,
especially those operating smaller vessels should avoid
navigating in these conditions.

properties.headline: Small Craft Advisory for Hazardous Seas issued November 1 at 3:07AM PDT expiring November 2 at 4:00PM PDT by NWS Portland OR
properties.description:
The National Weather Service in Portland has issued a Small Craft
Advisory for hazardous seas, which is in effect from 11 PM this
evening to 4 PM PDT Friday.

* WINDS...Southwest wind 15 to 20 kt with gusts to 25 kt late this
afternoon, becoming south 20 to 25 kt with gusts to 30 kt after
midnight. Then west winds 10 to 20 kt with gusts to 25 kt Friday
morning.

* SEAS...West swell 6 to 8 feet today building to around 10 feet
tonight. Seas will subside below 9 feet late Friday night.
properties.instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory for wind means that wind speeds of 21 to
33 knots are expected. Inexperienced mariners, especially those
operating smaller vessels should avoid navigating in these
conditions.

A Small Craft Advisory for hazardous seas means that waves are
expected to be hazardous to small craft. Mariners should avoid
shoaling areas. Long period swell can sharpen into large breaking
waves in shoaling areas. It is not unusual for waves to break
much farther from shoaling areas than is normally experienced.
Remember, breaking waves can easily capsize even larger vessels.

properties.areaDesc: Rapid City
properties.headline: Air Quality Alert issued November 1 at 3:35AM MDT by NWS Rapid City SD
properties.description:
A cold front will move through the area around midday. Northwest
winds will increase to 20 to 30 mph, with gusts to around 40 mph.
Winds will diminish after sunset. The gusty winds will suspend fine
dust in the air over west Rapid City, producing poor air quality.

The Rapid City Air Quality Office recommends the elderly, young,
and anyone with respiratory problems avoid excessive physical
exertion and exposure to the outside air.

Voluntary actions to reduce dust pollution include, ceasing or
reducing the manipulation of soil in construction, industrial,
and agricultural activities, and increasing the use of pollution
controls for soil stabilization, waste pits, stock piles, and
construction sites.

NWSheadline: AIR POLLUTION ALERT FOR DUST FOR RAPID CITY WEST OF THE GAP IN EFFECT FROM NOON UNTIL 700 PM

properties.headline: Lake Wind Advisory issued November 1 at 4:06AM CDT expiring November 1 at 3:00PM CDT by NWS Shreveport LA
properties.description:
A tight pressure gradient between surface low pressure over the
Lower Mississippi Valley and surface high pressure over West Texas
will result in strong and gusty winds of 15 to 20 MPH with higher
gust for parts of East and Northeast Texas.
The National Weather Service in Shreveport has issued a Lake Wind
Advisory, which is in effect from 9 AM this morning to 3 PM CDT
this afternoon.

* EVENT...A tight pressure gradient between surface low pressure
over the Lower Mississippi Valley and surface high pressure over
West Texas will result in strong and gusty winds of 15 to 20 MPH
with higher gust for parts of East and Northeast Texas.

* TIMING...From 9 AM CDT until 3 PM CDT today.

* IMPACT...Boaters should exercise caution due to increased winds
and a rough chop on area waterways for much of the day.
properties.instruction:

on area lakes. Small boats will be especially prone to capsizing.

mph with gust near 35 mph will be possible. Winds will slacken
some this afternoon as the strongest winds depart to the
northeast. Areas that have received heavy rainfall and have
saturated soils could see weakened or dying trees topple over in
some of the stronger wind gusts.

today before weakening while shifting to the north tonight. This
setup will support gusty south winds focused across higher
mountain elevations of western North Carolina through this
evening before gradually diminishing overnight.
The National Weather Service in Greenville-Spartanburg has issued
a Wind Advisory, which is in effect until 2 AM EDT Friday.

lines. Scattered power outages are expected.

properties.description:
The Flood Watch continues for

* A portion of western New York...including the following
counties...Allegany...Cattaraugus...Chautauqua...Genesee...
Livingston...Monroe...Niagara...Northern Erie...Orleans...
Southern Erie and Wyoming.

* From this afternoon through Friday afternoon.

* Widespread rain will develop today, will continue through
tonight and into early Friday across all of Western New York,
with the heaviest rain expected to fall between this afternoon
and this evening. Rainfall amounts of 1 to 2 inches are expected
through early Friday morning. This heavy rain will fall on
already saturated soils.

* Excessive runoff from heavy rainfall may result in minor
flooding of poor drainage areas and small creeks from late this
afternoon through early Friday morning, with minor flooding
also possible in areas where fallen leaves clog storm drains.
Minor flooding will also be possible on some of the larger
creeks and rivers on Friday, including the upper Genesee River,
upper Allegheny River, and Buffalo and Rochester area creeks.
properties.instruction:

current forecasts. You should monitor later forecasts and be
alert for possible flood warnings. Those living in areas prone to
flooding should be prepared to take action should flooding
develop. Stay tuned to weather radio or other radio and tv

properties.areaDesc: Coastal Wakulla; Coastal Franklin
properties.headline: Rip Current Statement issued November 1 at 4:10AM EDT expiring November 2 at 8:00AM EDT by NWS Tallahassee FL
properties.description:
The National Weather Service in Tallahassee has issued a High Rip
Current Risk, which is in effect through Friday morning.

* SURF HEIGHTS...Building to 4 to 6 feet.

* Impacts...The surf and frequent rip currents will be very
dangerous and life threatening for all level of swimmers.
properties.instruction:
A High Surf Advisory means that high surf will affect beaches in
the advisory area, producing localized beach erosion and
dangerous swimming conditions.

There is a high risk of rip currents.

Rip currents are powerful channels of water flowing quickly away
from shore, which occur most often at low spots or breaks in the
sandbar and in the vicinity of structures such as groins, jetties
and piers. Heed the advice of lifeguards, beach patrol flags and
signs.

If you become caught in a rip current, yell for help. Remain
calm, do not exhaust yourself and stay afloat while waiting for
help. If you have to swim out of a rip current, swim parallel to
shore and back toward the beach when possible. Do not attempt to
swim directly against a rip current as you will tire quickly.

NWSheadline: HIGH RIP CURRENT RISK IN EFFECT THROUGH FRIDAY MORNING

properties.description:
The National Weather Service in Tallahassee has issued a Gale
Warning, which is in effect until 8 PM EDT this evening. A Small
Craft Advisory has also been issued. This Small Craft Advisory is
in effect from 8 PM this evening to 2 AM EDT Friday. The Small
Craft Advisory is no longer in effect.

* WINDS...Southerly winds around 25 knots with gusts around 35
knots this morning into this evening. A line of thunderstorms
crossing the waters this afternoon may lead to wind gusts in
excess of 40 knots. Southerly winds will subside to around 20
knots later this evening into early tonight.

* WAVES/SEAS...Seas 6 to 9 feet with occasional seas up to 11
feet.
properties.instruction:
A Gale Warning means winds of 34 to 47 knots are imminent or
occurring. Operating a vessel in gale conditions requires
experience and properly equipped vessels. It is highly
recommended that mariners without the proper experience seek safe
harbor prior to the onset of gale conditions.

A Small Craft Advisory means that wind speeds of 21 to 33 knots
are expected to produce hazardous wave conditions to small craft.
Inexperienced mariners, especially those operating smaller
vessels should avoid navigating in these conditions.

properties.areaDesc: Harbor Beach to Port Sanilac MI; Port Sanilac to Port Huron MI; Outer Saginaw Bay SW of Alabaster to Port Austin MI to Inner Saginaw Bay; Port Austin to Harbor Beach MI
properties.headline: Small Craft Advisory issued November 1 at 3:46AM EDT expiring November 2 at 10:00PM EDT by NWS Detroit/Pontiac MI
properties.description:
Conditions today briefly governed by weak high pressure, maintaining
modest wind speeds and limited wave action. Winds will strengthen
from the northeast tonight in response to a strengthening low
pressure system tracking northeast across the Ohio valley. Moderate
northeast winds will then continue into Friday, provided an extended
period of onshore flow. This will result in elevated wave conditions
across the western basin of Lake Huron during this time, supporting
small craft advisory conditions over the nearshore waters and outer
Saginaw bay. Winds and waves will ease Friday night as the low
pressure exits to the east coast. Cool northerly flow will persist
across the region into the weekend.
The National Weather Service in Detroit/Pontiac has issued a
Small Craft Advisory which is in effect from midnight tonight to
10 PM EDT Friday.

* WIND AND WAVES: During the Small Craft Advisory, expect
sustained winds up to 18 knots from the northeast with gusts
up to 22 knots. The largest expected significant waves will
be 6 feet with a potential maximum wave height of 8 feet.

* TIMING: The maximum winds are expected around 12 AM EDT Friday
with the largest waves expected around 10 AM EDT Friday.

Refer to the latest marine forecasts for greater detail.
properties.instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means that wind speeds of 21 to 33 knots
are expected to produce hazardous wave conditions to small craft.
Inexperienced mariners...especially those operating smaller
vessels should avoid navigating in these conditions.

NWSheadline: SMALL CRAFT ADVISORY IN EFFECT FROM MIDNIGHT TONIGHT TO 10 PM EDT FRIDAY

properties.headline: Flood Watch issued November 1 at 3:44AM EDT expiring November 2 at 10:00AM EDT by NWS Cleveland OH
properties.description:
Rain will fill in this morning and increase in intensity today as
low pressure tracks from the Mid-Mississippi Valley this morning
to Northeast Ohio by this evening. Additional rainfall of 1.5 to 2
inches of rain is expected through tonight with locally higher
amounts possible. The axis of heaviest forecast rainfall continues
to shift westward and the watch has been expanded to include Huron
and Erie Counties in Ohio. This rain will lead to river rises and
flooding of low lying and poor drainage areas.
The National Weather Service in Cleveland has expanded the

* Flood Watch to include a portion of north central Ohio,
including the following areas, Erie and Huron.

* From 8 AM EDT this morning through Friday morning

* Additional rainfall of 1.5 to 2 inches with locally higher
amounts are likely.

* Rises on rivers, creeks, and streams are expected and may lead
to flooding. Flooding is also possible in other low lying and
flood prone areas. Strong northeast winds on Lake Erie this
afternoon and tonight may heighten the flood threat on rivers
flowing into the Lake.
properties.instruction:
A Flood Watch is issued when there is a potential for flooding.
Monitor the forecast and remain alert for possible flood
warnings. Those in areas prone to flooding should be prepared to
take action should a flood warning be issued or if flooding
develops.

generally north of the Ohio River.
The Flood Watch is now in effect for

* Portions of Indiana and Kentucky, including the following
areas, in Indiana, Clark, Crawford, Dubois, Floyd, Harrison,
Jefferson, Orange, Perry, Scott, and Washington. In Kentucky,
Breckinridge, Bullitt, Butler, Edmonson, Franklin, Grayson,
Hancock, Hardin, Harrison, Hart, Henry, Jefferson, Larue,
Logan, Meade, Nelson, Nicholas, Ohio, Oldham, Scott, Shelby,
Simpson, Spencer, Trimble, and Warren.

* Through this evening

* Total rainfall amounts in the watch area are expected to
average between 2 to 4 inches with locally higher amounts
possible. The best chance for localized amounts greater than 4
inches will be in southern Indiana and those areas in central
Kentucky that already received 2 to 3 inches Wednesday
evening.

* The rainfall will likely lead to nuisance flooding issues today
into tomorrow with quick rises on area creeks and streams. High
water will continue on some of the larger streams through the
end of the week.
properties.instruction:
A Flood Watch means there is a potential for flooding based on
current forecasts.

You should monitor later forecasts and be alert for possible
Flood Warnings. Those living in areas prone to flooding should be
prepared to take action should flooding develop.

NWSheadline: FLOOD WATCH NOW IN EFFECT THROUGH THIS EVENING

through this evening.

properties.instruction:
There is a high risk of rip currents.

Rip currents are powerful channels of water flowing quickly away
from shore, which occur most often at low spots or breaks in the
sandbar and in the vicinity of structures such as jetties and
piers. Heed the advice of lifeguards...beach patrol flags and
signs.

Swim near a lifeguard. If caught in a rip current, relax and
float. Don't swim against the current. If able, swim in a
direction following the shoreline. If unable to escape, face the
shore and call or wave for help.

properties.headline: Beach Hazards Statement issued October 31 at 7:58PM EDT expiring November 1 at 10:00PM EDT by NWS Tampa Bay Ruskin FL
properties.description:
* RED TIDE HAZARDS...Possible respiratory irritation in some
coastal areas.

For red tide forecast information visit
https://tidesandcurrents.noaa.gov/hab/gomx.html

* FLORIDA RED TIDE RESPIRATORY IRRITATION POTENTIAL IMPACTS...
Symptoms may include coughing...sneezing...and tearing eyes.
People with respiratory conditions such as asthma...
emphysema...and other pulmonary diseases may be more
sensitive. Irritation may vary locally and throughout the day.
If you experience uncomfortable symptoms...consider going to
an unaffected beach nearby.

* FLORIDA RED TIDE RESPIRATORY IRRITATION TIMING/LOCATION...NOAA
FORECAST:...Coastal southern Pinellas County: Gulf coast and bay
regions...possible Thursday.
properties.instruction:
Florida red tide observations...You can find unaffected beaches
by checking reports of recent local observations and data: Mote
Marine Laboratory daily beach conditions at
https://visitbeaches.org and the Florida Fish and Wildlife
Conservation Commission (FWC) red tide status at
myfwc.com/redtidestatus.

Florida red tide health information...Consult the Florida
Department of Health at: www.floridahealth.gov/environmental-
health/aquatic-toxins/red- tide.html or call the Poison Control
Center at: 1 800 222 1222.

Inclusion of external links does not constitute endorsement by
the Department of Commerce (DOC)/(NOAA) of these external web
sites or the information, products, or services contained
therein.

Florida red tide information sources...red tide forecasts are
provided by the National Ocean Service with data provided by the
FWC and Mote Marine Laboratory.

properties.areaDesc: Coastal Sarasota; Coastal Manatee
properties.headline: Beach Hazards Statement issued October 31 at 7:58PM EDT expiring November 1 at 10:00PM EDT by NWS Tampa Bay Ruskin FL
properties.description:
* RED TIDE HAZARDS...Possible respiratory irritation in some
coastal areas.

For red tide forecast information visit
https://tidesandcurrents.noaa.gov/hab/gomx.html

* FLORIDA RED TIDE RESPIRATORY IRRITATION POTENTIAL IMPACTS...
Symptoms may include coughing...sneezing...and tearing eyes.
People with respiratory conditions such as asthma...
emphysema...and other pulmonary diseases may be more
sensitive. Irritation may vary locally and throughout the day.
If you experience uncomfortable symptoms...consider going to
an unaffected beach nearby.

* FLORIDA RED TIDE RESPIRATORY IRRITATION TIMING/LOCATION...NOAA
FORECAST:...Coastal southern Manatee County: Gulf
coast...possible Thursday. Coastal northern Sarasota County:
Gulf coast...possible Thursday.
properties.instruction:
Florida red tide observations...You can find unaffected beaches
by checking reports of recent local observations and data: Mote
Marine Laboratory daily beach conditions at
https://visitbeaches.org and the Florida Fish and Wildlife
Conservation Commission (FWC) red tide status at
myfwc.com/redtidestatus.

Florida red tide health information...Consult the Florida
Department of Health at: www.floridahealth.gov/environmental-
health/aquatic-toxins/red- tide.html or call the Poison Control
Center at: 1 800 222 1222.

Inclusion of external links does not constitute endorsement by
the Department of Commerce (DOC)/(NOAA) of these external web
sites or the information, products, or services contained
therein.

Florida red tide information sources...red tide forecasts are
provided by the National Ocean Service with data provided by the
FWC and Mote Marine Laboratory.

properties.areaDesc: Upper Gila River and Aravaipa Valleys including Clifton/Safford; Eastern Cochise County Below 5000 Feet including Douglas/Willcox
properties.headline: Freeze Warning issued October 31 at 1:52PM MST expiring November 1 at 8:00AM MST by NWS Tucson AZ
properties.description:
* IMPACTS...These temperatures will damage sensitive crops and
vegetation that remain alive at this point in the season.

* TEMPERATURES...Morning lows in the upper 20s to lower 30s.

* TIMING...Approaching freezing by 2 AM MST in some locations,
with coldest temperatures between 5 AM and 7 AM.

* For a detailed view of the hazard area...visit
weather.gov/Tucson and click on the Detailed Hazards Icon
properties.instruction:
A Freeze Warning means sub-freezing temperatures are expected.
These temperatures will kill sensitive crops and vegetation.
Cover them...if possible...with cloth sheets or blankets to
protect them from freezing.

properties.areaDesc: Rusk, TX; Shelby, TX; Nacogdoches, TX; San Augustine, TX
properties.headline: Flood Warning issued October 31 at 10:11AM CDT by NWS Shreveport LA
properties.description:
The National Weather Service in Shreveport has issued a

* FLOOD WARNING FOR
the Attoyac Bayou Near Chireno, Texas.
* from Thursday morning until further notice...or until the warning
is cancelled.
* At 9:30 AM Wednesday The stage was 12.9 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 14 feet.
* Forecast...Rise above flood stage by Thursday morning and continue
to rise to near 15.5 feet by Saturday early afternoon.
* Impact...Minor lowland flooding.
properties.instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...


Do not drive vehicles through flooded waterways.  Use caution when
walking near flooded riverbanks.  Do not try to wade or swim in
flooded rivers and bayous.

For more hydrologic information, copy and paste the following website
address into your favorite web browser URL bar:
water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=shv

properties.areaDesc: Matagorda Bay
properties.headline: Small Craft Advisory issued October 31 at 9:58AM CDT expiring November 1 at 1:00PM CDT by NWS Houston/Galveston TX
properties.description:
Winds will strengthen this afternoon ahead of an approaching
cold front...Gulf seas building to 6 to 8 foot heights during the
evening hours. A cold front will move across the coastal waters
overnight into early Thursday morning. Strong to severe thunderstorms
will likely accompany this frontal passage later this afternoon
into the evening.
The National Weather Service in Houston/Galveston has issued a
Small Craft Advisory, which is in effect until 1 PM CDT Thursday.

* STRONG TO SEVERE THUNDERSTORMS along WITH a cold FRONTAL
PASSAGE TONIGHT into EARLY THURSDAY MORNING.

* WINDS...SOUTH WINDS 20 to 25 KNOTS with higher gusts BECOMING
WEST AND NORTHWEST OVERNIGHT AND THURSDAY MORNING.

* Sea State...Choppy to occasionally rough.
properties.instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means that wind speeds of 20 to 33 knots...
and/or seas 7 feet or higher...are expected to produce hazardous
conditions for small craft. Inexperienced boaters...especially
those operating smaller vessels should avoid navigating in these
conditions.

NWSheadline: SMALL CRAFT ADVISORY IN EFFECT UNTIL 1 PM CDT THURSDAY

properties.headline: Flood Warning issued October 31 at 4:08AM CDT expiring November 3 at 7:00PM CDT by NWS Milwaukee/Sullivan WI
properties.description:
Rock River At Afton affecting Rock County
Fox River Near Berlin affecting Green Lake County
The Flood Warning continues for
The Rock River At Afton.
* At  2:00 AM Wednesday the stage was 9.2 feet.
* Flood stage is 9.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Impact...At 9.1 feet...Floodwaters affect property of a home on
South Christian Road on the east side of the river in the Afton
area.  There is minor erosional flood damage to lowland and
agricultural land in the Afton and Janesville areas.
